objects.name: options
objects.string: Text

content.text: Text

objects.name: catq
objects.string:
Detective Dawgson:

a. Catrina, the stolen necklace—it’s become a point of interest. Can you explain how it came into your possession?

b. Catrina, you mentioned delivering fish to Ratatouille the night before his death. Can you tell me exactly what happened during that visit?

content.text:
Detective Dawgson:

a. Catrina, the stolen necklace—it’s become a point of interest. Can you explain how it came into your possession?

b. Catrina, you mentioned delivering fish to Ratatouille the night before his death. Can you tell me exactly what happened during that visit?

objects.name: catans1
objects.string: I wasn’t going to tell anyone, Detective, but... I’m running out of options. Business has been tough, the fish aren’t coming in like they used to, and I needed money—badly. I saw the necklace, and for a moment, it felt like a way out. But now, with everything going on, I know I’ve made a terrible mistake. If I’m caught, I’ll go to jail for sure. But it’s too late to undo what I’ve done. I just needed to survive, Detective.

content.text: I wasn’t going to tell anyone, Detective, but... I’m running out of options. Business has been tough, the fish aren’t coming in like they used to, and I needed money—badly. I saw the necklace, and for a moment, it felt like a way out. But now, with everything going on, I know I’ve made a terrible mistake. If I’m caught, I’ll go to jail for sure. But it’s too late to undo what I’ve done. I just needed to survive, Detective.

objects.name: catans2
objects.string: I brought the fish to his house, like I always do. The delivery was simple—just the usual order. I didn’t stick around long, didn’t talk to him much. He was busy with something, maybe paperwork, I don’t know. All I remember is I left after dropping off the order. I didn’t see anyone else there, and I certainly didn’t expect anything to go wrong. But now, with him dead, I’m the last one who saw him. That puts me in a very dangerous position, doesn’t it?

content.text: I brought the fish to his house, like I always do. The delivery was simple—just the usual order. I didn’t stick around long, didn’t talk to him much. He was busy with something, maybe paperwork, I don’t know. All I remember is I left after dropping off the order. I didn’t see anyone else there, and I certainly didn’t expect anything to go wrong. But now, with him dead, I’m the last one who saw him. That puts me in a very dangerous position, doesn’t it?

objects.name: chikq
objects.string:
Detective Dawgson:

a. Cluckie, your visions are impressive, but I need clarity. Did you meet with Ratatouille recently to offer your services? If so, what did you see before you left his home?

b. Cluckie, your vision of the cat is intriguing. But you say you see things others don’t—what about before the vision? Where were you, and what might have caught your eye that night?

content.text:
Detective Dawgson:

a. Cluckie, your visions are impressive, but I need clarity. Did you meet with Ratatouille recently to offer your services? If so, what did you see before you left his home?

b. Cluckie, your vision of the cat is intriguing. But you say you see things others don’t—what about before the vision? Where were you, and what might have caught your eye that night?

objects.name: chikans1
objects.string:
Cluckie:
Oh, Detective, I wasn’t going to mention it, but yes, I was at his house just a few hours before... the incident. He wanted me to read his fortune—said he had enemies circling him like vultures. As I left, I swear I caught a glimpse of something—or someone—lurking in the shadows. My vision afterward, the one of the cat being the killer... it all feels so connected now!

content.text:
Cluckie:
Oh, Detective, I wasn’t going to mention it, but yes, I was at his house just a few hours before... the incident. He wanted me to read his fortune—said he had enemies circling him like vultures. As I left, I swear I caught a glimpse of something—or someone—lurking in the shadows. My vision afterward, the one of the cat being the killer... it all feels so connected now!

objects.name: chikans2
objects.string:
Cluckie: 
It’s true, Detective—I see things others miss. That night, I was at Ratatouille’s house for a fortune-telling session. He seemed so troubled, asking about enemies and betrayal. As I left, I noticed a shadowy figure near the estate. At first, I thought nothing of it. But then, later, my vision came—the cat, the crime—it all makes sense now. Surely, that figure must have had something to do with it!

content.text:
Cluckie: 
It’s true, Detective—I see things others miss. That night, I was at Ratatouille’s house for a fortune-telling session. He seemed so troubled, asking about enemies and betrayal. As I left, I noticed a shadowy figure near the estate. At first, I thought nothing of it. But then, later, my vision came—the cat, the crime—it all makes sense now. Surely, that figure must have had something to do with it!

objects.name: bunq
objects.string:
Detective Dawgson:

a. Usagi, you mentioned you delivered carrots to the estate recently. Can you tell me more about that? Did you see Ratatouille while you were there?

b. Usagi, your farm is just outside Ratatouille’s property. Have you had any trouble with the land recently? Anything unusual going on?

content.text:
Detective Dawgson:

a. Usagi, you mentioned you delivered carrots to the estate recently. Can you tell me more about that? Did you see Ratatouille while you were there?

b. Usagi, your farm is just outside Ratatouille’s property. Have you had any trouble with the land recently? Anything unusual going on?

objects.name: bunans1
objects.string:
Usagi:

Yes, Detective, I delivered the carrots that morning, but I never saw Ratatouille himself. I only dealt with the cook—she took the whole crate and muttered something about preparing for a big dinner. I didn’t linger; I had too much work waiting back at the farm. Besides, I didn’t think it was my place to bother someone like him, especially with the way he treats us farmers.

content.text:
Usagi:

Yes, Detective, I delivered the carrots that morning, but I never saw Ratatouille himself. I only dealt with the cook—she took the whole crate and muttered something about preparing for a big dinner. I didn’t linger; I had too much work waiting back at the farm. Besides, I didn’t think it was my place to bother someone like him, especially with the way he treats us farmers.

objects.name: bunans2
objects.string:
Usagi:

Unusual? That’s putting it lightly, Detective. The land’s been ruined, poisoned by the chemicals Ratatouille’s company dumped near my fields. My carrots barely grow anymore, and what sprouts tastes bitter. I tried talking to him about it—pleading, really—but he didn’t care. Said my farm wasn’t worth the dirt it was planted on. Do you know what that feels like? Watching everything you’ve worked for rot away because of someone else’s greed?

content.text:
Usagi:

Unusual? That’s putting it lightly, Detective. The land’s been ruined, poisoned by the chemicals Ratatouille’s company dumped near my fields. My carrots barely grow anymore, and what sprouts tastes bitter. I tried talking to him about it—pleading, really—but he didn’t care. Said my farm wasn’t worth the dirt it was planted on. Do you know what that feels like? Watching everything you’ve worked for rot away because of someone else’s greed?

objects.name: catthink1
objects.string:
Detective Dawgson's Thoughts:

Hmm, seeing as Catarina is already a thief, it is evident she isn’t a law-abiding citizen. Maybe she’s the killer.

content.text:
Detective Dawgson's Thoughts:

Hmm, seeing as Catarina is already a thief, it is evident she isn’t a law-abiding citizen. Maybe she’s the killer.

objects.name: chikthink1
objects.string:
Detective Dawgson's Thoughts:

Hmm, Cluckie has to protect herself, could she possibly be the murderer?

content.text:
Detective Dawgson's Thoughts:

Hmm, Cluckie has to protect herself, could she possibly be the murderer?

objects.name: bunthink1
objects.string:
Detective Dawgson's Thoughts:

Hmm, Usagi seems to have a decent relationship with Ratatouille. And with them barely seeing each other face to face, I’m fairly sure the staff would have taken note of him if they’d seen him.

content.text:
Detective Dawgson's Thoughts:

Hmm, Usagi seems to have a decent relationship with Ratatouille. And with them barely seeing each other face to face, I’m fairly sure the staff would have taken note of him if they’d seen him.

objects.name: catthink2
objects.string:
Detective Dawgson's Thoughts:

Hmm, that certainly sounds like a very convenient excuse if Catarina is the killer… Catarina fits the profile of a detached and cold killer.

content.text:
Detective Dawgson's Thoughts:

Hmm, that certainly sounds like a very convenient excuse if Catarina is the killer… Catarina fits the profile of a detached and cold killer.

objects.name: chikthink2
objects.string:
Detective Dawgson's Thoughts:

Hmm, Cluckie has to protect herself, could she possibly be the murderer?

content.text:
Detective Dawgson's Thoughts:

Hmm, Cluckie has to protect herself, could she possibly be the murderer?

objects.name: bunthink2
objects.string:
Detective Dawgson's Thoughts:

Hmm, Usagi seems like an honest and upright soul, it can’t be possible for him to do such despicable things, moreover murder!

content.text:
Detective Dawgson's Thoughts:

Hmm, Usagi seems like an honest and upright soul, it can’t be possible for him to do such despicable things, moreover murder!

objects.name: Conviction_Option_Bar
objects.string:
Choose who is guilty
A. Catrina
B. Cluckie
C. Usagi

content.text:
Choose who is guilty
A. Catrina
B. Cluckie
C. Usagi

objects.name: wrongconviction
objects.string:
You made your choice, Detective. But justice can be a double-edged sword.

As the verdict is read, the true killer watches from the shadows, a sly smirk creeping across their face. With every step the innocent suspect takes toward their cell, the weight of your mistake grows heavier.

The crime remains unsolved, the real murderer free to walk the streets. Somewhere, another plan is unfolding, and you’re no closer to the truth.

content.text:
You made your choice, Detective. But justice can be a double-edged sword.

As the verdict is read, the true killer watches from the shadows, a sly smirk creeping across their face. With every step the innocent suspect takes toward their cell, the weight of your mistake grows heavier.

The crime remains unsolved, the real murderer free to walk the streets. Somewhere, another plan is unfolding, and you’re no closer to the truth.

objects.name: rightconviction
objects.string:
The case is closed, but the battle wasn’t just against the killer. It was against yourself—the doubts, the missteps, the temptation to rush to conclusions. Each clue tested your patience, every twist challenged your resolve. Yet here you stand, having unraveled the truth not just of this crime, but of your own growth.

By conquering your fears, embracing your instincts, and trusting the evidence, you’ve shown that even the greatest enemy—yourself—can be defeated with persistence and heart.

content.text:
The case is closed, but the battle wasn’t just against the killer. It was against yourself—the doubts, the missteps, the temptation to rush to conclusions. Each clue tested your patience, every twist challenged your resolve. Yet here you stand, having unraveled the truth not just of this crime, but of your own growth.

By conquering your fears, embracing your instincts, and trusting the evidence, you’ve shown that even the greatest enemy—yourself—can be defeated with persistence and heart.

objects.string:
Name: Ratatouille 
Time of death: 2024-11-24 02:30am
Location: House
Occupation: Owner of the Oil & Gas empire, Rodent & Co
Discovered by: A staff member of the manor

content.text:
Name: Ratatouille 
Time of death: 2024-11-24 02:30am
Location: House
Occupation: Owner of the Oil & Gas empire, Rodent & Co
Discovered by: A staff member of the manor

objects.name: Opening_Speech
objects.string:
Detective Dawgson arrives at Ratatouille's luxurious burrow estate, now cordoned off by police. 
Ratatouille's body lies lifeless in his living room. Scattered across the room are signs of a struggle, but no obvious weapon is found.
Explore this room to find out more about the crime…

Remember all responses are true!

When you have completed your investigation, select the killer by colliding with the gavel

Escape conversation by pressing the 'escape' key

content.text:
Detective Dawgson arrives at Ratatouille's luxurious burrow estate, now cordoned off by police. 
Ratatouille's body lies lifeless in his living room. Scattered across the room are signs of a struggle, but no obvious weapon is found.
Explore this room to find out more about the crime…

Remember all responses are true!

When you have completed your investigation, select the killer by colliding with the gavel

Escape conversation by pressing the 'escape' key

Detective Dawgson:

a. Cluckie, your visions are impressive, but I need clarity. Did you meet with Ratatouille recently to offer your services? If so, what did you see before you left his home?

b. Cluckie, your vision of the cat is intriguing. But you say you see things others don’t—what about before the vision? Where were you, and what might have caught your eye that night?

objects.name: chikans1
objects.string: Oh, Detective, I wasn’t going to mention it, but yes, I was at his house just a few hours before... the incident. He wanted me to read his fortune—said he had enemies circling him like vultures. As I left, I swear I caught a glimpse of something—or someone—lurking in the shadows. My vision afterward, the one of the cat being the killer... it all feels so connected now!

content.text: Oh, Detective, I wasn’t going to mention it, but yes, I was at his house just a few hours before... the incident. He wanted me to read his fortune—said he had enemies circling him like vultures. As I left, I swear I caught a glimpse of something—or someone—lurking in the shadows. My vision afterward, the one of the cat being the killer... it all feels so connected now!

objects.name: chikans2
objects.string: It’s true, Detective—I see things others miss. That night, I was at Ratatouille’s house for a fortune-telling session. He seemed so troubled, asking about enemies and betrayal. As I left, I noticed a shadowy figure near the estate. At first, I thought nothing of it. But then, later, my vision came—the cat, the crime—it all makes sense now. Surely, that figure must have had something to do with it!

content.text: It’s true, Detective—I see things others miss. That night, I was at Ratatouille’s house for a fortune-telling session. He seemed so troubled, asking about enemies and betrayal. As I left, I noticed a shadowy figure near the estate. At first, I thought nothing of it. But then, later, my vision came—the cat, the crime—it all makes sense now. Surely, that figure must have had something to do with it!

objects.name: bunq
objects.string:
Detective Dawgson:

a. Usagi, you mentioned you delivered carrots to the estate recently. Can you tell me more about that? Did you see Ratatouille while you were there?

b. Usagi, your farm is just outside Ratatouille’s property. Have you had any trouble with the land recently? Anything unusual going on?

content.text:
Detective Dawgson:

a. Usagi, you mentioned you delivered carrots to the estate recently. Can you tell me more about that? Did you see Ratatouille while you were there?

b. Usagi, your farm is just outside Ratatouille’s property. Have you had any trouble with the land recently? Anything unusual going on?

objects.name: bunans1
objects.string:
Usagi:

Yes, Detective, I delivered the carrots that morning, but I never saw Ratatouille himself. I only dealt with the cook—she took the whole crate and muttered something about preparing for a big dinner. I didn’t linger; I had too much work waiting back at the farm. Besides, I didn’t think it was my place to bother someone like him, especially with the way he treats us farmers.

content.text:
Usagi:

Yes, Detective, I delivered the carrots that morning, but I never saw Ratatouille himself. I only dealt with the cook—she took the whole crate and muttered something about preparing for a big dinner. I didn’t linger; I had too much work waiting back at the farm. Besides, I didn’t think it was my place to bother someone like him, especially with the way he treats us farmers.

objects.name: bunans2
objects.string:
Usagi:

Unusual? That’s putting it lightly, Detective. The land’s been ruined, poisoned by the chemicals Ratatouille’s company dumped near my fields. My carrots barely grow anymore, and what sprouts tastes bitter. I tried talking to him about it—pleading, really—but he didn’t care. Said my farm wasn’t worth the dirt it was planted on. Do you know what that feels like? Watching everything you’ve worked for rot away because of someone else’s greed?

content.text:
Usagi:

Unusual? That’s putting it lightly, Detective. The land’s been ruined, poisoned by the chemicals Ratatouille’s company dumped near my fields. My carrots barely grow anymore, and what sprouts tastes bitter. I tried talking to him about it—pleading, really—but he didn’t care. Said my farm wasn’t worth the dirt it was planted on. Do you know what that feels like? Watching everything you’ve worked for rot away because of someone else’s greed?

Hmm, seeing as Catarina is already a thief, it is evident she isn’t a law-abiding citizen. Maybe she’s the killer.

objects.name: wrongconviction
objects.string:
You made your choice, Detective. But justice can be a double-edged sword.

As the verdict is read, the true killer watches from the shadows, a sly smirk creeping across their face. With every step the innocent suspect takes toward their cell, the weight of your mistake grows heavier.

The crime remains unsolved, the real murderer free to walk the streets. Somewhere, another plan is unfolding, and you’re no closer to the truth.

content.text:
You made your choice, Detective. But justice can be a double-edged sword.

As the verdict is read, the true killer watches from the shadows, a sly smirk creeping across their face. With every step the innocent suspect takes toward their cell, the weight of your mistake grows heavier.

The crime remains unsolved, the real murderer free to walk the streets. Somewhere, another plan is unfolding, and you’re no closer to the truth.

objects.name: rightconviction
objects.string:
The case is closed, but the battle wasn’t just against the killer. It was against yourself—the doubts, the missteps, the temptation to rush to conclusions. Each clue tested your patience, every twist challenged your resolve. Yet here you stand, having unraveled the truth not just of this crime, but of your own growth.

By conquering your fears, embracing your instincts, and trusting the evidence, you’ve shown that even the greatest enemy—yourself—can be defeated with persistence and heart.

content.text:
The case is closed, but the battle wasn’t just against the killer. It was against yourself—the doubts, the missteps, the temptation to rush to conclusions. Each clue tested your patience, every twist challenged your resolve. Yet here you stand, having unraveled the truth not just of this crime, but of your own growth.

By conquering your fears, embracing your instincts, and trusting the evidence, you’ve shown that even the greatest enemy—yourself—can be defeated with persistence and heart.
